Title:
Good News is Rwandair not only upgraded their aircrafts but also the quality of their Business Class services. We flew in the Boeing 737-800.

The planes have been refurbished to an as new feel. Could be new??? In-cabin service, food service, drinks service have gone up a few notches. Duty free service is now available. For us, the client service in general is now exceptional and customer responsive. My husband has glaucoma. Though he can walk, he requires assistance especially in those very long airport corridors.

On a previous trip we travelled with a Nigerian sportsperson whom everyone seemed to be greeting. I never realized how serious his condition was until a stretcher fetched him from the airport cabin, and an emergency team was ready for him just outside immigration.

I have been flying Rwandair from Accra to Johannesburg over five years now....always business class. I can charge my phone and iPad from my seat, watch movies from my individual screen, listen to the latest internal music, or enjoy their top quality cabin magazine is top quality.

The food and drinks menu reminds me of British Airways in quality, healthiness, and presentation. The drinks service is impeccable save for lack of honey and rooibos tea. South African rooibos is the in health tea. Black, white or green Rwanda tea would have been a lovely novelty.

This airline is price competitive and gives a 50% saving over flying direct from Accra to Johannesburg. There is a stopover in Lagos or Abuja, and a brief change of aircrafts in Kigali.

The Kigali Lounge is of international stands and beats Orly in Paris in bathroom quality.

Oh Boy, immigration is fussy even with transit passengers.

We have encountered business travellers and diplomats not flying their national career. Could be the routes, the service, or cost factor.

Door to door the trip is 10 hours. The downside or upside is the flight arrives at about 2am in Johannesburg. Check in is 11.30 returning.

The plus is Business Class passengers now have a 3 bag allowance each at 20kg. A fourth might be added if one has points. This comes in handy should an artifact or two catch your fancy, carry or bring back too many gift items, or enjoy shopping when travelling.


Nothing so far has motivated us to change. not even the fact that we always miss duty-free shopping.

On the day of my flight, I was stuck in Nairobi traffic so I reached out to the airline via social media to see what would happen if I missed my flight (as RwandAir has an afternoon and evening flight departure).  To this day I still have not received a response from them, but luckily I made it to the airport in time.  RwandAir provides two checked bags for free, but I only had one bag so check-in was very easy and efficient; my luggage was tagged and I received my boarding pass.The operating aircraft for this flight was a CRJ aircraft, which generally are small and tiny.  The aircraft was parked on an aircraft stand so boarding passes were collected in the airport and then we walked to the aircraft.  The aircraft was laid out in a 2-2 seat layout and generally the seats were comfortable and the legroom was extremely good (I am tall and I had more than enough legroom).  Boarding a bit chaotic as there was no order to the process, with everyone trying to board at once and people having difficulty finding their seats.  The attendants on board were not particularly interested in helping any of the passengers nor in speeding up the boarding process.  Boarding finally completed, the door was closed, manual safety demonstrations were conducted, and we taxied to the runway.  This is another instance where the attendants were not really paying attention as the passenger sitting next to me did not understand the safety demonstrations, did not understand English, and was sitting without her seatbelt on.  I motioned twice for the flight attendants but they seemed least bothered.  It was only while doing their final safety checks did I repeat the information to the flight attendant and they finally paid attention. While the plane is taxing to the runway I was made to switch to a bulkhead seat – and even here most airlines make you put your hand-carry in the overhead compartment to keep the aisle clear.  On this flight, the attendants seemed least bothered.  After waiting for a while we finally took off for the 1hr 25m flight time. Once we reached cruising altitude, the inflight service commenced.  The attendants came by with a drink cart and a meal cart.  Even though I had ordered a special meal and the special meal was delivered onboard, it was not marked for a particular seat assignment nor with my name.  Another passenger, who had not pre-ordered a special meal but requested one onboard was given my special meal.  When I asked for the meal, they said they only had one and it had been given away so the option was to give me the regular tray of the sides without the main meal; I passed on that option.  When the drink cart came, it was limited as it only had juice, water, and alcohol.  I asked for a soft drink and they said they did not have it nor could they get it for me so I ended just taking water.  In both the drink and meal service, the attendants attitude was a ‘take it or leave it’; they couldn’t care less.  After the service concluded, there was not much to do for the remainder of the flight.  There were no PTV screens nor any inflight entertainment system.  The seats had compartment up top which held the airline magazine, the airsickness bag, as well as the duty free catalog.  There was also a tray table below and another holder beneath that to store other items.  There were no USB ports and I could not find any electrical outlets either.   We started our descent into Kigali and the attendants came by to do their last safety checks, and again they really did not pay attention to seatbacks being upright nor to ensure everyone had their seatbelts on.We landed into Kigali generally on time and taxied to a stand (there are no airline bridges at Kigali International) and deplaned via the stairs.  The stairs on the plane are very narrow and can be slippery, especially when it is raining as it was in Nairobi, and because of that three passengers slipped and fell coming down the stairs.  For this reason, the airline made the passengers go down the stairs very slowly so deplaning took a while.  After deplaning we boarded the bus which took us to the arrivals hall.Overall, I was disappointed with my RwandAir flight.  I was really looking forward to their flight, as I was told by others about their good service and I see how active they are on social media.  Despite my high expectations, everything the flight was a miss.  The customer service was lacking, the inflight service was poor, and the overall experience was lacking.  The only positives about the experience was the ease of booking the flight and the generous legroom.  Given this experience, I would not choose to fly RwandAir again.

Things didn't get off to a terific start when our flight from Entebbe to Kigali left half an hour late but the plane was new and the seats comfortable which is all you can hope for on a forty 40 minute Flight.

Our next leg from Kigali to Brussells was a further hour late in departing with the Captain explaining that this was due to the plane arriving late from its previous flight. This explanation is always bemusing given that it is one airline.

Again the best thing that could be said was that the cabin was in very good condition and not surprisingly so given the plane is less than a year old. The business section was not very full so we expected lots of attention from the cabin crew but this was not be the case.

We had ordered a vegtarian meal and were served up what was clearly lunch for breakfast. I suggested as much to the steward but he was insistent. For some reason hash browns with grilled mushrooms and baked beans were not considered suitable for a vegatrian breakfast but fried bananas and chickpeas were. At lunch we were served the same sauce with rice confirming that we were indeed served the lunch offering for breakfast.

Unlike the normal business class where staff are almost pestering to serve you drinks and snacks this was not to be on this particular flight. When I asked for water at one stage the steward seemed to remember he should have been serving the passengers and clutched several bottles and went through the cabin offering water to everyone. The sleep quality was good given the flat bed fold out of the seat.

The on board entertainment system is sparsely populated if one is being kind, if you are able to carry your own content do so. The inflight wifi did not work on the outward leg of the journey whilst on the return leg it did work albeit for 15 minutes whereupon you could purchase a limited bundle that was also time limited.

Our return flight also left nearly an hour and a half late, again for the same reason that our initial flight was late, someone keeps taking these planes for a joyride it would seem.
The cabin was once again sparsely populated and the meal service more in line with the offerings in economy which was packed. We were even served a meaty salad with our vegetarian meal which is always a nice touch.

Our return flight was topped off with the discovery that our luggage did not return with us. Thankfully it all came in intact albeit a day late and was delivered to our door.

One would struggle to find a business class ticket to the UK from Equatorial Africa at a price that is no more than 50% over economy on most of the other airlines and that is perhaps the best thing that can be said of this airline. In all other aspects they are very much still finding their feet with their marketing department clearly doing a much better job than their training, customer care and ground handling departments. If all you need is the extra legroom, a flatbed seat, and use of a lounge at the airport plus some queue jumping then for the price this is the airline for you.

Title:
These were flights seven and eight in the space of three weeks with RwandAir and once again did the airline live up to expectations.
I managed to wait for boarding at the airline's lounge in Lagos after a problem free check in and going through immigration and security.
The ground handling staff, after carrying out a final body and hand baggage check at the gate, then boarded business class passengers first, followed by Premium Economy passengers - RwandAir has no doubt the best such option in the African skies with extra legroom, wider seats and deep recline before boarding economy class passengers.
Once on board, business class was more than three quarters full, did the crew do their thing with taking one's jacket for hanging up in a wardrobe cabinet, offered a choice of drinks and topped it with steaming hot towels to wipe the sweat off one's face.
The food and drink service, after reaching cruising level, was swift and the smoked salmon starter was fresh and tasted good. More buns, and butter, was offered when the main course was served, then followed by a plate of select cheeses and rounded up by an offering of dessert.
If I had to add anything it would be offering a printed menu to passengers to be aware of the meal choices before the service which would be the icing on the cake no doubt for many passengers.
Upon landing was my jacket returned immediately without having to ask for it.
The aircraft was parked close to the arrival building, no need for a bus and within a few steps was I inside the building, reached the transfer desk and had my onward boarding pass from Kigali to Entebbe stamped.
Transit was 'rapid', only a short queue at the Business Class / VIP security lane - this puts Entebbe airport to shame where no such facilities exist - and I boarded my last sector flight home which took just over half an hour from take off to landing. Connecting with RwandAir to West Africa and to Southern Africa clearly is the fastest option for a passenger from Uganda and I have no hesitation to book WB again for future flights to these parts of Africa.

Title:
This was my 6th flight with RwandAir in the space of just 14 days and again I did not regret my choice of airline as I was flying from Entebbe via Kigali to Lagos.
Not only is this the fastest possible connection between Uganda and Nigeria but also the most comfortable.
The 1x2x1 configured business class section offers excellent comfort levels and the state of the art flatbed seats leave nothing to be desired - in fact a massage function is an added extra many other airlines do not provide.
I spent my connecting time, just over an hour between flights, in the Pearl Lounge at Kigali International Airport and, when called for boarding, used the separate security channel for business class passengers. Same procedures of course but notably a notch friendlier and certainly no queues to get to the boarding gate. The plane was parked nearby and I was able to walk to the stairs and a ground staff again fast tracked my boarding when seeing my C-class boarding pass.
When entering the plane I was warmly greeted and told by a cabin crew member that I was free to move to a window seat of my choice as the load on the day was light upfront.
Captain Cobbina Kojo even greeted me - other passengers too - before he returned to the cockpit to complete his preflight checks.
Purserette Laetitia Umuzayire and her colleague Edwige Munezero were as keen as cabin crew ever come, a delight to be served by them.
On the flight to Lagos was a full breakfast offered, with a choice of buns and/or pastries, freshly cut fruits - no seeds at all in the water melon slices!!! - and then followed by an omelette with baked beans and notably roasted gonja, a type of sweet banana, adding local flavour to the morning meal. I was even asked if I'd wanted some more food but politely declined.
I had mentioned to Miss Laetitia that I would like my tea cup to be refilled ever so often and she did exactly that while I concentrated to first scan through the entertainment channels before deciding to read a book I brought. Time flew by and the four hour flight was over in no time.
A warm good bye and hope to see you again, delivered by both front cabin crew, made for a very pleasant exit.
Another excellent flight with RwandAir!
